Award.AwardTitle: Local Scales and Multi-Scale Representations of Images
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigator and his colleagues study the problem of extracting features of images and their properties via scales and local scales using the classical theory of function spaces and partial differential equations. They use the knowledge of scales and local scales in images to obtain an efficient method for image decompositions and multiscale representations, which are image dependent. Finally, they extend the theory of scales and local scales to higher dimensional data (graphs and manifolds), and to find efficient computational methods and algorithms to solve these problems.

Reducing a complex data to simpler representations that can be more easily analyzed is an important task in mathematics and information science. The study of scales and local scales provides a tool for doing this task. In particular, it provides a tool for organizing and clustering the internal multiscale structures of the data.
Applications include medical imaging, hyperspectral imaging, satellite imaging, material science, terrain data analysis, and dimension reduction in higher dimensional data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PI proposed new methods to study scale and feature detection in images and on curves and surfaces via diffusions. The objects of studies are an image f and a positive measure mu defined on a d-dimensional surface embedded on an n-dimensional Euclidean space. The theory involved convolving the objects with kernels of zero mean at various scales and detecting changes in scales. These changes are viewed as deviations from a linear function in the case of an image and from a d-plane in the case of a d-dimensional surface. This is intimately related to the study of singular integrals on the n-dimensional Euclidean space and its extension to curves and surfaces.

 

The outcomes and findings of the proposed project include:

1) Six articles published in refereed scientific journals and four preprints on new mathematical theories and computational techniques to study local scales in images and on curves and surfaces and their applications.

2) The PI further disseminated the published results through presentations at seminars and conferences.The published results are also displayed on the PI's homepage. The PI also organized a special session at the Imaging Science Conference on the proposed project.

3) The PI offered independent and seminar courses to undergraduate and graduate students on the materials related to the proposed project. The PI also offered a Summer course on Image Analysis in Vietnam to expose the students to the Image Processing field.

4) For professional training, the PI attended summer programs and workshops on the research field related to the proposed project.
